org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
We conducted theoretical studies on the physics of dusty plasmas. Dusty plasmas are ionized gases that contain electrons, ions, neutral atoms, and small (nanometers to tens of microns) solid particles, or dust grains, that are electrically charged. Dust occurs in cosmic environments, such as noctilucent clouds in the Earth's mesosphere, comets, Saturn's rings, and star-forming regions in interstellar space. Dust can also occur in terrestrial plasmas, such as industrial plasmas used for materials processing. Dusty plasmas are studied in dedicated laboratory experiments where the typically micron-size grains are negatively charged, and can be observed using laser light scattering. In experiments, the dust can also be strongly coupled (i.e., the electrostatic potential energy between dust grains exceeds their kinetic energy) resulting in liquid-like or crystalline plasma states.

 

We conducted theoretical studies of waves, and instabilities that excite waves, in weakly coupled and strongly coupled dusty plasmas. The focus was on low frequency dust waves that are associated with the motion of the charged dust. This research centered on advancing the basic understanding of dust waves and instabilities needed to interpret current experiments and motivate new experiments. Spurred by the advent of new dusty plasma experimental devices with high magnetic field, several studies focused on waves in dusty plasmas in magnetic fields. Results included predictions of (i) the behavior of dust wave instabilities driven by magnetized ion flows, when the dust motion is either magnetized or unmagnetized, and (ii) the behavior of waves in strongly coupled dusty plasmas composed of paramagnetic dust that interact via electrostatic and magnetic dipole forces. Instabilities in magnetized plasmas containing heavy negative ions were also studied, as this can provide insights into similar instabilities in dusty plasmas. In addition, waves in strongly coupled dusty plasmas without magnetic fields were studied. Results included predictions of (a) the effect of strong coupling on the excitation of dust waves, and (b) the behavior of waves when the interaction between dust grains is modified by external electric fields. Our research results were reported in 11 publications in refereed journals.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2016
Modified by: Marlene C Rosenberg
